<!-- 2. Go to Tools: Import in the WordPress admin panel. -->
<!-- 3. Install the "WordPress" importer from the list. -->

		<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:6:{s:5:"width";s:3:"300";s:6:"height";s:3:"100";s:14:"hwstring_small";s:23:"height='42' width='128'";s:4:"file";s:31:"2012/03/blog.aijay_.id_.au_.png";s:5:"sizes";a:1:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:31:"blog.aijay_.id_.au_-150x100.png";s:5:"width";s:3:"150";s:6:"height";s:3:"100";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";s:1:"0";s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";s:1:"0";s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";s:1:"0";s:3:"iso";s:1:"0";s:13:"shutter_speed";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_context</wp:meta_key>

	<item>
				<title>Resume</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/?attachment_id=137</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 Jun 2012 05:50:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/Resume.docx</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>137</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-06-04 05:50:18</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-06-04 05:50:18</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>resume</wp:post_name>

	<item>
				<title>cropped-cwan.png</title>

	<item>
				<title>cwan3 Management Connectivity</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2013/10/cwan3-bgp-diverse-management/cwan_routing/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 Oct 2013 22:33:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/cwan_routing.png</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[cwan3 Management Connectivity]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>230</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-10-20 08:33:07</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-10-19 22:33:07</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>cwan_routing</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>228</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
				<title>Aquila Media Alerts</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2010/11/aquila-media-alerts/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 24 Nov 2010 02:11:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=26</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[How do you know you have too much digital media? you spend a couple of days writing a series of silly python scripts to catalogue it and alert you of new content! (ok, so it's no lightbulb joke... moving on). The point is that in my house I share a NAS with my housemates, it offers us 6TB of storage and everyone can access it. The problem sometimes is knowing when new content has been added, sure it's easy enough to sort the 'movies' folder by date and see what's new, but no such convenience is available for the heavily structured branches such as tv.

There are a couple of ways I can think of to approach this problem,
<ul>
	<li>The tv branch could be restructured into one folder, that is to say, unstructured. This would work but does present two immediate issues. A) many many many files in one node, and B) Naming conventions would have to be perfectly applied or there is a real risk of content becoming lost.</li>
	<li>Create a database with date modified information and use that to find latest content. This has the disadvantage of being practically redundant as it is replicating filesystem information</li>
</ul>
Despite the apparent redundancy I decided the best path was to create a database with all the files in the tv and movies branches of the NAS along with their modification dates, this would be a simple task and would allow for simple manipulation and presentation of the data.
<pre style="background-color: #fff; padding: 1em;"><code><span style="color: #000;">
<pre style="background-color: #fff; padding: 1em;"><code><span style="color: #555;">#!/usr/bin/python</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #00c;">import</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">os</span><span style="color: #000;">, </span><span style="color: #000;">datetime</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #00c;">import</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">MySQLdb</span><span style="color: #000;">

</span><span style="color: #555;"># Reset lastupdate time</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #000;">os</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">remove</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #f39;">"/multimedia/movies/lastupdate"</span><span style="color: #000;">)
</span><span style="color: #000;">f</span><span style="color: #000;">=</span><span style="color: #000;">open</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #f39;">'/multimedia/movies/lastupdate'</span><span style="color: #000;">, </span><span style="color: #f39;">'w'</span><span style="color: #000;">)

</span><span style="color: #555;"># Connect to DB</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #000;">db</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #000;">MySQLdb</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">connect</span><span style="color: #000;"> (    </span><span style="color: #000;">host</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #f39;">"localhost"</span><span style="color: #000;">,
                           </span><span style="color: #000;">user</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #f39;">"username"</span><span style="color: #000;">,
                           </span><span style="color: #000;">passwd</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #f39;">"password"</span><span style="color: #000;">,
                           </span><span style="color: #000;">db</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #f39;">"media"</span><span style="color: #000;">)
</span><span style="color: #000;">cursor</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #000;">db</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">cursor</span><span style="color: #000;">()

</span><span style="color: #555;"># Remove lastupdate from database</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #000;">cursor</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">execute</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #f39;">"DELETE FROM `files` WHERE `path` = </span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #f39;">'/multimedia/movies/lastupdate'</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">LIMIT</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #369;">1</span><span style="color: #f39;">")</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #555;"># Load files in database</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #000;">cursor</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">execute</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #f39;">"SELECT * from `files`"</span><span style="color: #000;">)
</span><span style="color: #555;"># Create a list to store the files loaded from the database</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #000;">files</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #000;">list</span><span style="color: #000;">();
</span><span style="color: #555;"># Loop through all database enteries</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #00c;">while</span><span style="color: #000;"> (</span><span style="color: #369;">1</span><span style="color: #000;">):
    </span><span style="color: #000;">row</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #000;">cursor</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">fetchone</span><span style="color: #000;"> ()
    </span><span style="color: #00c;">if</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">row</span><span style="color: #000;"> == </span><span style="color: #00c;">None</span><span style="color: #000;">:
        </span><span style="color: #00c;">break</span><span style="color: #000;">
    </span><span style="color: #555;"># Add database enteries to List</span><span style="color: #000;">
    </span><span style="color: #000;">files</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">append</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">row</span><span style="color: #000;">[</span><span style="color: #369;">1</span><span style="color: #000;">])

</span><span style="color: #555;"># Define directories to scan for files</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #000;">basedir</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #000;">list</span><span style="color: #000;">()
</span><span style="color: #000;">basedir</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">append</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #f39;">"/multimedia/tv"</span><span style="color: #000;">)
</span><span style="color: #000;">basedir</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">append</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #f39;">"/multimedia/movies"</span><span style="color: #000;">)

</span><span style="color: #555;"># Add new Files</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #00c;">for</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">dir</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #00c;">in</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">basedir</span><span style="color: #000;">:
    </span><span style="color: #555;"># Get contense of directory</span><span style="color: #000;">
    </span><span style="color: #00c;">for</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">f</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #00c;">in</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">os</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">listdir</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">dir</span><span style="color: #000;">):
        </span><span style="color: #555;"># If the entry is a file</span><span style="color: #000;">
        </span><span style="color: #00c;">if</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">os</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">path</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">isfile</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">os</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">path</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">join</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">dir</span><span style="color: #000;">, </span><span style="color: #000;">f</span><span style="color: #000;">)):
            </span><span style="color: #000;">db_file</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #000;">os</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">path</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">join</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">dir</span><span style="color: #000;">, </span><span style="color: #000;">f</span><span style="color: #000;">)
            </span><span style="color: #555;"># Check if the file is already in the database</span><span style="color: #000;">
            </span><span style="color: #00c;">if</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #00c;">not</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">db_file</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #00c;">in</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">files</span><span style="color: #000;">:
                </span><span style="color: #555;"># Log to Database</span><span style="color: #000;">
                </span><span style="color: #000;">db_file</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #000;">db_file</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">replace</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #f39;">"'"</span><span style="color: #000;">, </span><span style="color: #f39;">"\'"</span><span style="color: #000;">)
                </span><span style="color: #000;">db_date</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #000;">datetime</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">datetime</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">fromtimestamp</span><span style="color: #000;">(
                </span><span style="color: #000;">os</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">path</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">getmtime</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">os</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">path</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">join</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">dir</span><span style="color: #000;">, </span><span style="color: #000;">f</span><span style="color: #000;">)))
                </span><span style="color: #000;">sql</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #f39;">"INSERT INTO  `media`.`files` 
                (`path` ,`date`) VALUES ('"</span><span style="color: #000;">
                </span><span style="color: #000;">sql</span><span style="color: #000;"> += </span><span style="color: #000;">str</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">db_file</span><span style="color: #000;">) 
                </span><span style="color: #000;">sql</span><span style="color: #000;"> += </span><span style="color: #f39;">"',  '"</span><span style="color: #000;"> 
                </span><span style="color: #000;">sql</span><span style="color: #000;"> += </span><span style="color: #000;">str</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">db_date</span><span style="color: #000;">)
                </span><span style="color: #000;">sql</span><span style="color: #000;"> += </span><span style="color: #f39;">"');"</span><span style="color: #000;"> 
                </span><span style="color: #000;">cursor</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">execute</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">sql</span><span style="color: #000;">)
        </span><span style="color: #555;"># If the entry is a directory</span><span style="color: #000;">
        </span><span style="color: #00c;">else</span><span style="color: #000;">:
            </span><span style="color: #555;"># Add directory to search list</span><span style="color: #000;">
            </span><span style="color: #000;">basedir</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">append</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">os</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">path</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">join</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">dir</span><span style="color: #000;">, </span><span style="color: #000;">f</span><span style="color: #000;">))

</span><span style="color: #555;"># Remove Old Files</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #00c;">for</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">f</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #00c;">in</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">files</span><span style="color: #000;">:
    </span><span style="color: #00c;">if</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #00c;">not</span><span style="color: #000;"> </span><span style="color: #000;">os</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">path</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">isfile</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">f</span><span style="color: #000;">):
        </span><span style="color: #555;"># Remove entry from database</span><span style="color: #000;">
        </span><span style="color: #000;">f</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #000;">f</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">replace</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #f39;">"'"</span><span style="color: #000;">, </span><span style="color: #f39;">"\'"</span><span style="color: #000;">)
        </span><span style="color: #000;">sql</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #f39;">"DELETE FROM `files` WHERE `path` = '</span><span style="color: #000;">
        </span><span style="color: #f39;">" + f + "</span><span style="color: #f39;">' LIMIT 1"</span><span style="color: #000;">
        </span><span style="color: #000;">cursor</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">execute</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">sql</span><span style="color: #000;">)

</span><span style="color: #000;">db</span><span style="color: #000;">.</span><span style="color: #000;">close</span><span style="color: #000;">()</span></code></pre>
</span></code></pre>
With this database checking for new files still felt a little bit silly, so I scheduled the following script to email out notifications of new files each day. Now we can be lazy and informed!
<pre style="background-color: #fff; padding: 1em;"><code>
<span style="color: #369;">&lt;?php</span><span style="color: #000;">
</span><span style="color: #555;"># Connect to DB
</span><span style="color: #00c;">require</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #f39;">'db_connect.php'</span><span style="color: #000;">);

</span><span style="color: #555;"># Select files added in the last 24 Hours
</span><span style="color: #555;"># (exclude the lastupdate file)
</span><span style="color: #000;">$sql</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #f39;">'SELECT * FROM `files` WHERE
        `date` &gt; NOW() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND
        `path` NOT LIKE '/multimedia/movies/lastupdate' '</span><span style="color: #000;">;
</span><span style="color: #000;">$result</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #1181b7;">mysql_query</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">$sql</span><span style="color: #000;">);

</span><span style="color: #555;"># Count how many files have been added
</span><span style="color: #00c;">if</span><span style="color: #000;">((</span><span style="color: #000;">$count</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #1181b7;">mysql_num_rows</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">$result</span><span style="color: #000;">)) &gt; </span><span style="color: #369;">0</span><span style="color: #000;">){
    </span><span style="color: #555;"># New Files exist
</span><span style="color: #000;">
    </span><span style="color: #555;"># Configure Alert Email
</span><span style="color: #000;">    </span><span style="color: #000;">$to</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #f39;">'aijay, kyle, mick'</span><span style="color: #000;">;
    </span><span style="color: #000;">$subject</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #000;">$count</span><span style="color: #000;"> . </span><span style="color: #f39;">' New AquilaMedia Files'</span><span style="color: #000;">;

    </span><span style="color: #555;"># Message Body
</span><span style="color: #000;">    </span><span style="color: #000;">$message</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #f39;">'
    &lt;!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd"&gt;
    &lt;html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"&gt;
    &lt;head&gt;
    &lt;meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" /&gt;
    &lt;style type="text/css"&gt;
    body,td,th {
        font-family: Tahoma, Geneva, sans-serif;
        font-size: small;
        color: #333;
    }
    body {
        background-color: #FFF;
    }
    &lt;/style&gt;
    &lt;/head&gt;

    &lt;body&gt;
    &lt;p&gt;&lt;img src="http://aquila.newanglesey.com.au/media/aquilamedia.png" width="262" height="113" alt="aquilamedia" /&gt;
    &lt;/p&gt;
    &lt;p&gt;These files have been added to aquila&lt;strong&gt;media&lt;/strong&gt; in the last 24 hours.&lt;/p&gt;
    &lt;p&gt; &lt;/p&gt;
    &lt;p&gt;'</span><span style="color: #000;">;

    </span><span style="color: #555;"># Place filename of new files in message body
</span><span style="color: #000;">    </span><span style="color: #00c;">while</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">$row</span><span style="color: #000;"> = </span><span style="color: #1181b7;">mysql_fetch_assoc</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">$result</span><span style="color: #000;">)){
        </span><span style="color: #000;">$message</span><span style="color: #000;"> .= </span><span style="color: #000;">$row</span><span style="color: #000;">[</span><span style="color: #f39;">'path'</span><span style="color: #000;">] . </span><span style="color: #f39;">"&lt;br /&gt;"</span><span style="color: #000;">;
    }

    </span><span style="color: #000;">$message</span><span style="color: #000;"> .= </span><span style="color: #f39;">'&lt;/p&gt;
    &lt;/body&gt;
    &lt;/html&gt;'</span><span style="color: #000;">;

    </span><span style="color: #555;"># Build HTML Mail Headers
</span><span style="color: #000;">    </span><span style="color: #000;">$headers</span><span style="color: #000;">  = </span><span style="color: #f39;">'MIME-Version: 1.0'</span><span style="color: #000;"> . </span><span style="color: #f39;">"rn"</span><span style="color: #000;">;
    </span><span style="color: #000;">$headers</span><span style="color: #000;"> .= </span><span style="color: #f39;">'Content-type: text/html; charset=iso-8859-1'</span><span style="color: #000;"> . </span><span style="color: #f39;">"rn"</span><span style="color: #000;">;
    </span><span style="color: #555;"># Build AUX Headers
</span><span style="color: #000;">    </span><span style="color: #000;">$headers</span><span style="color: #000;"> .= </span><span style="color: #f39;">'From: Aquila Media &lt;media@aquila.newanglesey.com.au&gt;'</span><span style="color: #000;"> . </span><span style="color: #f39;">"rn"</span><span style="color: #000;">;

    </span><span style="color: #00c;">if</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #1181b7;">mail</span><span style="color: #000;">(</span><span style="color: #000;">$to</span><span style="color: #000;">, </span><span style="color: #000;">$subject</span><span style="color: #000;">, </span><span style="color: #000;">$message</span><span style="color: #000;">, </span><span style="color: #000;">$headers</span><span style="color: #000;">)){
        </span><span style="color: #00c;">echo</span><span style="color: #000;"> (</span><span style="color: #f39;">'Alert Sent'</span><span style="color: #000;">);
    }</span><span style="color: #00c;">else</span><span style="color: #000;">{
        </span><span style="color: #00c;">echo</span><span style="color: #000;"> (</span><span style="color: #f39;">'Alert Failed'</span><span style="color: #000;">);
    }
}</span><span style="color: #00c;">else</span><span style="color: #000;">{
    </span><span style="color: #555;"># No New Files to Alert
</span><span style="color: #000;">    </span><span style="color: #00c;">echo</span><span style="color: #000;"> (</span><span style="color: #f39;">'No New Files'</span><span style="color: #000;">);
}</span></code></pre>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Linux NAS with ZFS-FUSE</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2011/03/linux-nas-with-zfs-fuse/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 13 Mar 2011 06:05:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=53</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Before dedicating to using ZFS-FUSE to create the array I thought it would be good to test what sort of performance hit we could expect. Afer all, the Atom powered machine isn't exactly a super computer. Results looking OK.

<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/Screen-shot-2011-03-13-at-5.03.57-PM.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-54" title="ZFS speed test" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/Screen-shot-2011-03-13-at-5.03.57-PM.png" alt="" width="651" height="790" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>53</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-03-13 06:05:59</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-03-13 06:05:59</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

	<item>
				<title>A useful regex for TV episodes</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2011/04/a-useful-regex-for-tv-episodes/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 Apr 2011 09:27:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=57</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">I have a fair bit of messy media, this went a long way to cleaning it up. Maybe it will be helpful to you, or maybe you can suggest a more robust expression.</div>
<div></div>
<div>
<pre>rename -v 's/.(?!([S]{3}$))/ /gi' *
rename -v 's/[_]/ /gi' *
rename -v 's/([w*|s]*)(-*).*s([d]{2})e([d]{2}).*(.[S]{3}$)/$1- s$3e$4$5/gi' *</pre>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>57</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-04-04 09:27:27</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-04-04 09:27:27</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>a-useful-regex-for-tv-episodes</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="debian"><![CDATA[debian]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="home-network"><![CDATA[Home Network]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="media"><![CDATA[Media]]></category>

	<item>
				<title>crust free firday</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2011/04/crust-free-firday/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 18 Apr 2011 08:55:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=59</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

Crust is pretty cool, I don't know anyone who doesn't like it. The only problem is that they are very expensive. Fear not, as crust run a promotion every friday where they give away free pizzas to one l

ucky twitter follower. The promotion is aptly named 'crust free friday'. There is no chance that I would actually remember to enter the promotion on anything resembling a regular basis, so in order to get into the competition and increase my chances of getting to eat crust goodness I have employed the best tool for any periodic task, cron.
<pre>aijayadams@taco:~$ crontab -l
35 09 * * 5 /home/aijayadams/crust_free_friday</pre>
<pre>aijayadams@taco:~$ cat crust_free_friday
#!/bin/bash
twidge update "I'm entering @Crust_Pizza #CrustFreePizzaFriday 
cos I'm hungry and I like crust pizza (and so does my bf @aaronjacobc :D)"</pre>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>59</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-04-18 08:55:18</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-04-18 08:55:18</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>crust-free-firday</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="just-nerdy"><![CDATA[Just Nerdy]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
				<title>About</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/about/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 23 Nov 2010 23:28:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.aijay.id.au/?page_id=2</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Good day!

I'm Aijay Adams, I have an honours degree in computer engineering from the University of Wollongong. Currently I work as a Technology Specialist at Telstra Corporation where I get to develop things on a scale I'd never imagined! This is a blog of my personal adventures in technology and in no way represents the view of Telstra (standard disclaimer etc...)

[caption id="attachment_280" align="aligncenter" width="288"]<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/aijay_id_au_profile2.png"><img class="size-medium wp-image-280" alt="Aijay Adams (it's me!)" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/aijay_id_au_profile2-288x300.png" width="288" height="300" /></a> Aijay Adams (it's me!)[/caption]

Today I work as a Technology Specialist in Aggregation Network Engineering at Telstra in the Sydney CBD. Business as usual is providing engineering oversight and escalated operational support, managing lifecycle and capacity, as well as maintaining views on performance and inventory within networks containing almost 20,000 elements. The networks I work with deliver an extraordinary breadth of services across a truly national footprint, from broadband delivered to remote schools over microwave links to the 10GB/s direct to the Internet backbone required by Data Centres.
The heterogeneous nature of the services, and environments in which they are delivered requires the use of many hardware platforms from a myriad of vendors. While there is certainly a lot of Cisco, to perform effectively requires a working knowledge of Juniper, Alcatel, F5, FibreLAN, Palo Alto and RAD just to name a few.

Finally, although certainly not least is my more than passing acquaintance with the humble scripting languages, Shell, Perl, and Python. When managing not just devices, but services across a network the size of Telstra’s the ability to quickly craft scripts, whether they be for information gathering, application of new configuration directives, or service provisioning, is invaluable.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>139</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-11-23 23:28:25</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-11-23 23:28:25</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>about</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

	<item>
				<title>Flash Freeze</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2010/11/flash-freeze/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 24 Nov 2010 01:17:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=4</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Inspired by the recent <a href="http://www.engadget.com/2010/11/07/diyer-builds-handsfree-arduino-powered-remote-camera-trigger-v/">engadget article</a> it was decided that making a sound triggered flash would be a great idea to pass some time. Fortunately it's pretty simple if you happen to have the following laying around,
<ul>
	<li>Arduino of some type (any will do).</li>
	<li>Optical Isolator (MC3021).</li>
	<li>Camera with full manual mode.</li>
	<li>External flash.</li>
	<li>Speaker.</li>
</ul>
I have used the Arduino Mega 2560, a Canon EOS 450D, an external flash which has more years on this planet then me and an old speaker that was in a box in the garage. If like me you have lots of crap just hanging around chances are the only thing you will need to buy is the MC3021 optical isolator, which is a common component available for less then $1 at your local Jaycar store.

A sensible starting point  is to devise a way to trigger your flash, this should be easy as many flashes have a PC socket. If not you can choose to do one of three things,
<ol>
	<li>Get creative and connect some wires directly to the hot shoe.</li>
	<li>Buy a hot shoe to PC sync adaptor.</li>
	<li>Take your flash apart and find the wires you need (probably only suitable for an old flash you don't intend to use in the conventional way again)</li>
</ol>
My flash, being super old and not really suitable for conventional use anymore suffered option 3, this also allowed me to feed it power from a small switch-mode supply rather then supplying it AA batteries. If this is the route you choose be mindful that there are <em><strong>high</strong></em> <em><strong>voltages inside a flash, enough to hur</strong></em><strong><em>t</em></strong> if you touch the wrong parts.

<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/IMG_5644.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-7" title="Arduino Sound Triggered Flash" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/IMG_5644.png" alt="Arduino Sound Triggered Flash" width="551" height="503" /></a>

Now that you have all the components you need and have devised a suitable method for triggering your flash it's time to connect it to your Arduino board. Use a digital IO pin as a trigger for the optical isolator, and connect your flash trigger across the output of the isolator, this way, when you bring the IO pin high the optical isolator will close the circuit and trigger the flash without exposing your Arduino to any high voltage components.

In order to trigger on sound we must have the Arduino listening, an old speaker works well enough for this task, remembering that the principal of a microphone and speaker are identical, just driven from different ends of the model. So we can connect the speaker between ground and an analogue input on the Arduino, when the value we sample from the analogue input is above a particular threshold we trigger the flash. In my case, this threshold is zero as the speaker only responds to very loud noises, you're experience may vary.

Finally here is the code loaded on the Arduino, you will notice that each time the flash is triggered an additional 50ms delay is inserted between the next noise and flash trigger, this is so I could vary the delay before the flash in the field to discover the best delay for a variety of photographs. It turns out 100ms is pretty good for shattering bottles!

Arduino Code:

<code>int lastState = 0;
int flashPin = 2;</code>

<code> </code>

<code>void setup(){
pinMode(flashPin, OUTPUT);
}
void loop(){
int sensorValue = analogRead(A0);
if (sensorValue &gt; 1){
delay(50 * lastState);
digitalWrite(flashPin, HIGH);
delay(50);
digitalWrite(flashPin, LOW);
lastState = lastState + 1;
}
}</code>

<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/MG_5636.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-13" title="Flash Freeze - Green" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/MG_5636.png" alt="" width="748" height="511" /></a><a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/asjdklfjklads.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-18" title="Freeze White" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/asjdklfjklads.png" alt="" width="748" height="545" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>140</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-11-24 01:17:35</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-11-24 01:17:35</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>flash-freeze</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="arduino"><![CDATA[Arduino]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="photography"><![CDATA[Photography]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="tech-stuff"><![CDATA[Tech Stuff]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_thumbnail_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[7]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_old_slug</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>yubikey PAM on Debian 6</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/?p=172</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quatre.aijay.id.au/blog.aijay.id.au/?p=172</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Many years ago I started to learn the basics of networking playing with <a href="http://www.ipcop.org/">IPCop</a> and Windows 2000 with Routing and Remote Access. It was a simple time when <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_address_translation">NAT</a> and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pptp">PPTP</a> ruled the land. There is a good chance I would never have moved on if it weren't for a gentleman who introduced me to the world of Debian and iptables.

This man was a CCIE Security, the first I knew. He taught me a great deal, but one thing stands out, "security is a state of mind".

A lot of time has passed and I now have academic and professional experience of my own, the more I experience the real world of networking, the more I agree.

&nbsp;

Debian Specific Fix:

cp /usr/local/lib/security/pam_yubico.* /lib/security/

<code>## YubiKey Config
# Administrative Level
auth required pam_yubico.so authfile=/etc/yubikeyid id=9556 debug
#OR
# User Level
# auth required pam_yubico.so id=16 debug </code>

# Read environment variables from /etc/environment and
# /etc/security/pam_env.conf.
auth required pam_env.so # [1]
# In Debian 4.0 (etch), locale-related environment variables were moved to
# /etc/default/locale, so read that as well.
auth required pam_env.so envfile=/etc/default/locale

# Standard Un*x authentication.
@include common-auth

# Disallow non-root logins when /etc/nologin exists.
account required pam_nologin.so

# Uncomment and edit /etc/security/access.conf if you need to set complex
# access limits that are hard to express in sshd_config.
# account required pam_access.so

# Standard Un*x authorization.
@include common-account

# Standard Un*x session setup and teardown.
@include common-session

# Print the message of the day upon successful login.
session optional pam_motd.so # [1]

# Print the status of the user's mailbox upon successful login.
session optional pam_mail.so standard noenv # [1]

# Set up user limits from /etc/security/limits.conf.
session required pam_limits.so

# Set up SELinux capabilities (need modified pam)
# session required pam_selinux.so multiple

# Standard Un*x password updating.
@include common-password]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/bg_aijay_id_au_blog4.png</guid>

			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:1600;s:6:"height";i:1000;s:4:"file";s:32:"2014/02/bg_aijay_id_au_blog4.png";s:5:"sizes";a:4:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:32:"bg_aijay_id_au_blog4-150x150.png";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:9:"image/png";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:32:"bg_aijay_id_au_blog4-300x187.png";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:187;s:9:"mime-type";s:9:"image/png";}s:5:"large";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:33:"bg_aijay_id_au_blog4-1024x640.png";s:5:"width";i:1024;s:6:"height";i:640;s:9:"mime-type";s:9:"image/png";}s:14:"post-thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:32:"bg_aijay_id_au_blog4-624x390.png";s:5:"width";i:624;s:6:"height";i:390;s:9:"mime-type";s:9:"image/png";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_is_custom_background</wp:meta_key>

	<item>

	<item>
				<title>Aijay Adams</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/about/aijay_id_au_profile/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 15 Feb 2014 00:38:26 +0000</pubDate>

	<item>
				<title>Project: Basil</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2011/05/project-basil/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 14 May 2011 07:47:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=66</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Check out this new video I made about my latest project. It's pretty cool and the video isn't too long, so watch it! :)
<div align="center">
<iframe width="480" height="390" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/dBT8semYt10" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
</div>

]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>66</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-05-14 07:47:31</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-05-14 07:47:31</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>project-basil</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="just-nerdy"><![CDATA[Just Nerdy]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="tech-stuff"><![CDATA[Tech Stuff]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Network Switch</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2011/05/network-switch/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 14 May 2011 11:21:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=78</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>For reasons that are beyond the scope of what I can explain in this short post I needed to ability to reset access points from ~500KM away. It will come as no surprise to those who know me that this was a challenge readily accepted.</p>

<p>
Luckely, AustralianRobotics had just send me their fortnightly email and in the front was a large image of the EtherTen, and Ardunio Uno compatible board with a build in Ethernet shield. I thought this was the perfect machine for the job so I decided to try it out.
</p>

<p>
The code below is based uses the standard Ethernet library and works smashingly! As a result I ordered some more!,</p>

<pre lang="c">
#include <SPI.h>

#include <Client.h>
#include <Ethernet.h>
#include <Server.h>
#include <Udp.h>
#include <string.h>

char c;
char input = 0;
int bufindex = 0;

// For sending HTML to the client
#define STRING_BUFFER_SIZE 128
char buffer[STRING_BUFFER_SIZE];
char compare[STRING_BUFFER_SIZE];

byte mac[] = { 0xDE, 0xAD, 0xBE, 0xEF, 0xFE, 0xED };
byte ip[] = { 192, 168, 1, 101 };
byte gateway[] = { 192, 168, 1, 1 };
byte subnet[] = { 255, 255, 255, 0 };

Server server = Server(80);

void setup(){

  // Reset Pin
  pinMode(2,OUTPUT);

  Ethernet.begin(mac, ip, gateway, subnet);
  server.begin();
}

void loop(){
  Client client = server.available();
  if (client) {
    // an http request ends with a blank line
    boolean current_line_is_blank = true;
    while (client.connected()) {
    if (client.available()) {

        buffer[0]= client.read();
        buffer[1] = client.read();      

        bufindex = 2;

        while ((buffer[bufindex-2] != 'r' || buffer[bufindex-2] != 'n') && buffer[bufindex-1] != 'n') { // read full row and save it in buffer
           c = client.read();
           if (bufindex<STRING_BUFFER_SIZE) buffer[bufindex] = c;
           bufindex++;
        }
        // send a standard http response header
        client.println("HTTP/1.1 200 OK");
        client.println("Content-Type: text/html");
        client.println();
        client.print("netswitch,");
        strcpy(compare, "GET ");
        if(!strncmp(compare, buffer, 4)){
          // Read HTTP request
          if(buffer[6] == 'o' && buffer[6] == 'n'){
            // On
            client.println("on");
            digitalWrite(2,LOW);
          }else if (buffer[6] == 'o' && buffer[6] == 'f' && buffer[7] == 'f'){
            // Off
            digitalWrite(2,HIGH);
            client.println("off");
          }else if (buffer[5] == 'r' && buffer[6] == 's' && buffer[7] == 't'){
            // Reset
            digitalWrite(2,HIGH);
            delay(5000);
            digitalWrite(2,LOW);
            client.println("rst");
          }
          break;
       }
     }
     delay(1);
     client.stop();
   }
  }
}
</pre>
]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>network-switch</wp:post_name>

	<item>
				<title>Network Switch, Auto Reset</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2011/05/network-switch-auto-reset/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 29 May 2011 22:30:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=89</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As of my previous <a href="http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=78">post</a> resetting a locked up access-point remotely is as simple as a web request, so why not issue that request automatically as soon as access to the device is lost?
<pre lang="perl">
#!/usr/bin/perl

while(1){
    # Check for access point
    @output = `ping -c 1 192.168.0.5`;

    # If access point is down
    if (join(" ", @output) =~ /0 received/i){
       # Turn off
       `wget 192.168.1.101/oof -O /dev/null`;
       sleep(3);
       # Turn On
       `wget 192.168.1.101/on -O /dev/null`;
       # Wait 2 minutes for access point to reload
       sleep(120);
    }
# Wait 15 seconds
sleep(15);
# Ensure switch is alive and on
`wget 192.168.1.101/on -O /dev/null`;
}
</pre>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

				<title>BLIP-D1 Prototype</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2011/11/blip-d1-prototype/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Nov 2011 03:36:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=99</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The first step in our follow up to <a href="http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=66">Project Basil</a>. A new, friendly web interface and more flexible physical display.


<iframe width="560" height="315" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/jGgGtOgZqAw?rel=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>IPSEC VPN Cisco IOS to Juniper ScreenOS</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2012/03/ipsec-vpn-cisco-ios-to-juniper-screenos/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 22 Mar 2012 08:23:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://blog.aijay.id.au/?p=109</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Let's be clear, even some professionals think IPSEC is scary, this is particularly the case when configuring heterogeneous devices. In this post I wanted to record my experiences setting up a simple Site-to-Site IPSEC VPN between my house, powered by a Juniper Netscreen SSG20 and a good friends house, powered by a Cisco 857. Our networks, Taco and Pizza, are addressed 10.58.68.0/24 and 10.42.41.0/24 respectively. The relevant network topology is show in the diagram below. (And no, I'm not nearly cool enough to own 1.1.1.1 or 2.2.2.2, but we shall pretend to avoid having internet muppets target my home router)

<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/TacoPizzaVPN.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-132" title="PizzaNet to TacoNet VPN" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/TacoPizzaVPN.png" alt="" width="930" height="404" /></a>

First up let's properly define the hardware and software in use, that way if you copy me exactly and it doesn't work you can blame version differences.

Pizza Router:
<ul>
	<li>Cisco 857W, Cisco IOS Software, C850 Software (C850-ADVSECURITYK9-M), Version 12.4(15)T11, RELEASE SOFTWARE (fc2)</li>
</ul>
Taco Router:
<ul>
	<li>Juniper SSG20-WLAN, ScreenOS 6.3.0r10.0, Type: Firewall+VPN</li>
</ul>
<h3></h3>
<h3>Configuring the Juniper SSG20 (or other ScreenOS device)</h3>
Now we can jump into some ScreenOS commands, I realise there is a pretty GUI, and ScreenOS is not fluid or intuitive to use on the CLI in general. Trust me, this is easier on the command line...
<pre>set address "Trust" "taco-net" 10.58.68.0 255.255.255.0
set address "Untrust" "pizza-net" 10.42.41.0 255.255.255.0
set interface tunnel.6 ip unnumbered interface adsl1/0
set interface "tunnel.6" zone "Untrust"
set ike gateway "toPizza_GW" address 1.1.1.1 Main outgoing-interface "adsl1/0" preshare "MYKEY" proposal "pre-g2-3des-sha"
set vpn "toPizza_VPN" gateway "toPizza_GW" no-replay tunnel idletime 0 proposal "g2-esp-3des-sha"
set vpn "toPizza_VPN" bind interface tunnel.6
set vpn "toPizza_VPN" proxy-id local-ip 10.58.68.0/24 remote-ip 10.42.41.0/24 "ANY"
set route 10.42.41.0/24 interface tunnel.6 preference 20 permanent
set policy id 8 from "Trust" to "Untrust" "taco-net" "pizza-net" "ANY" permit
set policy id 9 from "Untrust" to "Trust" "pizza-net" "taco-net" "ANY" permit</pre>
Easy isn't it! In my experience the complexity in IPSEC arises from the flexibility available in encryption and hashing protocols available in the multi phase negotiation. In this configuration we are keeping life simple by sticking with a 3DES / SHA combination for all phases of the negotiation and IPSEC connection. Also note that unless you too are a crazy person you can probably use the "tunnel.1", I have been told normal people don't have much use for tunnel interfaces in their home networks.
<h3>Configuring the Cisco 857 (or other IOS device)</h3>
This is pretty much just a mirror of the above config, as you might expect, translated for IOS.
<div>
<pre>crypto isakmp policy 1
 encr 3des
 hash sha
 authentication pre-share
 group 2
 lifetime 3600
crypto isakmp key 0 MYKEY address 2.2.2.2
!
crypto ipsec transform-set 3des-sha esp-3des esp-sha-hmac
!
crypto map ipsec-taco 1 ipsec-isakmp
 set peer 2.2.2.2
 set transform-set 3des-sha
 set pfs group2
 match address 101
!
access-list 101 permit ip 10.42.41.0 0.0.0.255 10.58.68.0 0.0.0.255
!
interface Dialer 1
 crypto map ipsec-taco</pre>
</div>
<div>There is one very important additional step for the IOS device if you, like me, have chosen to be lazy and simply applied the crypto map on the public interface of a home router (which will almost in variably be performing PAT on that interface). In order to match our ACL on public interface we must prevent traffic bound for the VPN from being PAT'd, or it won't match the SA's for the VPN. In my case this looks like the config below.</div>
<div>
<pre>ip nat inside source list 180 interface Dialer1 overload
access-list 180 deny ip 10.42.41.0 0.0.0.255 10.58.68.0 0.0.0.255
access-list 180 permit ip 10.42.41.0 0.0.0.255 any</pre>
And that's it folks! I want to thank the guys at <a href="http://blog.mozilla.com/mrz/2007/07/16/ipsec-vpn-between-cisco-ios-netscreen-solved/" target="_blank">mrz's noise Mozilla Blog</a>, their post was very helpful once my thoughts migrated from "this will be trivial" to "a straight gre tunnel will do the job".

</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

				<title>Junos at Home</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2012/11/junos-at-home/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 07 Nov 2012 21:53:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quatre.aijay.id.au/blog.aijay.id.au/?p=145</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[So here is a quick post to say thank you to @cooperlees and Kyle for facilitating the upgrade of my trusty SSG-20 to a shiny new SRX110. Now the kit has been upgraded it's time to build some cool network ;)

[caption id="attachment_146" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/A7EQJHZCQAAL2bL.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-146 " title="Cooper with SRX110" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/A7EQJHZCQAAL2bL-300x224.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="224" /></a> My limited edition #2 SRX110 signed by Cooper.[/caption]]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>New Mid-Way Station</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2012/11/new-mid-way-station/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 07 Nov 2012 22:15:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quatre.aijay.id.au/blog.aijay.id.au/?p=154</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[cwan is a network my great friend John and I built starting in 2005! I haven't written about it here, but I think it's about time that changed!

To start you off here is a picture of the new Mid-Way station which John recently rebuilt. This station is exclusively solar powered and serves to split what had perviously been a 30KM single hop! Oh yeah, cwan is probably a little more than your average home WiFi network.

<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/IMG_4272.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-157" title="cwan3 Mid-Way Station November 2012" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/IMG_4272-682x1024.jpg" alt="" width="584" height="876" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>154</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

	<item>
				<title>Junos Space iOS</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2012/11/junos-space-ios/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 07 Nov 2012 22:59:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quatre.aijay.id.au/blog.aijay.id.au/?p=161</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/20121108-095814.jpg"><img class="alignnone " src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/20121108-095814.jpg" alt="20121108-095814.jpg" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>161</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-11-08 08:59:23</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-11-07 22:59:23</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>junos-space-ios</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="junos"><![CDATA[Junos]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="networking"><![CDATA[Networking]]></category>
		<category domain="post_format" nicename="post-format-image"><![CDATA[Image]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>geo_latitude</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>geo_longitude</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[151.207902]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>geo_public</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Virtual Routing and Forwarding (VRF) in Linux</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2012/11/virtual-routing-and-forwarding-vrf-in-linux/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 09 Nov 2012 05:11:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://quatre.aijay.id.au/blog.aijay.id.au/?p=163</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[If you addressed a private network at anytime in the last 17 years you would have been well advised to select your address space from the IANA reserved <a href="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1918">RFC1918</a> ranges. At the time the RFC was published I was a whole 7 years old, and my computer skills may have extended as far as 'if' statements in batch scripts learnt from the MS-DOS Version 5 User Guide. It would be at least another 2 or 3 years before I would come to understand the most basic concepts of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_protocol_suite">TCP/IP</a>.

Despite the age of the private network reserved address ranges many networks are older, and through what I can only assume is a combination of ignorance and avoidance some of these networks still use public address space on private networks. If the operator of the private network owns the public space the worst we can really say is that the operator is being wasteful. If the operator of the private network doesn't own the public space, or has reused it in the public internet the conflict is left for network administrators and engineers to handle.

So let's picture the problem, a private network using public addresses which are also advertised on the internet.

<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Linux-VRF.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-165" title="Address Overlap" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Linux-VRF.png" alt="" width="1024" height="768" /></a>

As you can see, its not a problem until the need arises to provide a common service. Once you attempt to do this the standard methodology of routing packets based on destination address breaks down. How do we know if a packet should be sent to 1.1.1.0/24 on the private network or 1.1.1.0/24 on the internet?

<em>NB. I know routing breaks more generally at this boundary, but we all know about <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_Routing_and_Forwarding">VRF</a> or virtual-routers on our network devices.</em>

The problem is relatively simple, we have overlapping address space so we need to consider some additional information in order to forward the packet to the correct router. Since our server has separate local interfaces (physical or virtual), one private network facing and the other internet facing we can configure iproute2 to install a different route for the overlapping 1.1.1.0/24 network on each interface. Once these separate routing tables have been established it is possible to service request from the overlapping networks as responses originating from requests on the private network facing interface will be forwarded to the private network router, similarly, responses originating from requests on the internet facing interface will be forwarded to the internet router!

First step is to create some additional routing tables which we will bind to each of our interfaces. We do this by editing the file <code>/etc/iproute2/rt_tables<code>.</code></code>
<pre class="lang:default decode:true">#
# reserved values
#
255	local
254	main
253	default
0	unspec
#
# local
#
1	pri-net	
2	internet
</pre>

Now that we have created the new routeing tables we can associate them with the logical interfaces we use to access our private network and internet routers.
<pre class="lang:default decode:true">ip rule add iif eth1 table pri-net prio 100
ip rule add iif eth0 table internet prio 100</pre>
Next we will populate these new routing tables with the information they need to deliver packets. You will notice we are adding the local subnet manually, this is important because the automagic process of adding the directly connected subnets to the routing table only occures for the default routing table, and without a directly connected network iproute2 doesn't know how to access the default gateway.
<pre class="lang:default decode:true">ip route add 10.0.1.0/24 table pri-net dev eth1 proto static scope link
ip route add 1.1.1.0/24 via 10.0.1.254 table pri-net dev eth1 proto static

ip route add 10.0.2.0/24 table internet dev eth0 proto static scope link
ip route add 1.1.1.0/24 via 10.0.2.254 table internet dev eth0 proto static</pre>


Finally iproute2 needs to be told witch routing table to use when packets originate from a local address.
<pre class="lang:default decode:true">ip rule add from 10.0.1.1/32 lookup pri-net
ip rule add from 10.0.2.1/32 lookup internet</pre>


We're done! Your host can now deliver services to the overlapping address ranges by selecting the routing table based on the source address of the response. You can view the routes installed in each routing table with the ip route commands.
<pre class="lang:default decode:true">ip route list table internet
ip route list table pri-net</pre>


In my book it's pretty cool that this functionality is so simple in linux, but remember it is always better to address private networks with the reserved address ranges.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>163</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-11-09 15:11:43</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-11-09 05:11:43</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>virtual-routing-and-forwarding-vrf-in-linux</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="just-nerdy"><![CDATA[Just Nerdy]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="linux"><![CDATA[linux]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="networking"><![CDATA[Networking]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="routing"><![CDATA[routing]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="vrf"><![CDATA[vrf]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>dsq_thread_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1870661937]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>SSH Authentication, Private Key + YubiKey</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2013/01/ssh-authentication-private-key-yubikey/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 18 Jan 2013 03:32:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://aijay.id.au/blog/?p=189</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_190" align="alignleft" width="219"]<img class="size-full wp-image-190 " alt="YubiKey" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/yubikey.jpg" width="219" height="147" /> YubiKey[/caption]

Does your home network really need the protection of two-factor authentication? Probably not, but Yubico have made it so easy to do that you should probably implement it anyway.

There are an unimaginable variety of ways to integrate YubiKey two-factor authentication into almost any device, service or platform. There exist PAM modules, Windows Server components, Java libraries, C libraries, Active X and Secure Web APIs to verify one time passwords [<a href="http://www.yubico.com/develop/open-source-software/low-level-library/">http://www.yubico.com/develop/open-source-software/low-level-library/</a>]. You can choose to utilise the <a style="line-height: 1.714285714; font-size: 1rem;" href="http://www.yubico.com/products/services-software/yubicloud/">YubiCloud </a>validation servers, or install your own either as a virtual appliance, PHP Application or Python Application [<a style="line-height: 1.714285714; font-size: 1rem;" href="http://www.yubico.com/develop/open-source-software/validation-server/">http://www.yubico.com/develop/open-source-software/validation-server/</a>].

The variety is so great it seems almost overwhelming at first (at least, that is how I felt). I’m going to share with you what I think is a good place to start, it may not be the most complete deployment, but it will give you a good feel for how you can use your new two-factor authentication.

Before obtaining my Yubikeys I used a Private Key to authenticate to my home Linux box, and I encountered a little bit of uncomfortable confusion when the realisation that I would be unable to use the YubiPAM module in concert with my Private Key settled in. Fortunately for all of us caught in this situation <a href="https://www.berrange.com">Daniel Berrange</a> wrote a very useful <a href="https://www.berrange.com/posts/2011/12/18/multi-factor-ssh-authentication-using-yubikey-and-ssh-public-keys-together/">post</a>, including some example code, explaining how he was able to overcome this problem.

In summary, the user is logged in using their SSH Private Key as normal. Once the user has been logged in the 'ForceCommand' parameter of SSHD spawns a shell script which prompts for the one time password and performs YubiKey verification. Only when verification is successful is the standard user shell invoked.

While Daniel's method works brilliantly, I have a requirement which requires a slight modification from his method. In order to allow SCP using clients such as transmission, I only want one time passwords to be required for a subset of users.

[caption id="attachment_197" align="alignnone" width="811"]<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/2013/01/ssh-authentication-private-key-yubikey/ssh-authentication-flow/"><img class="size-full wp-image-197 " alt="Two Factor SSH Authentication Flow" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/SSH-Authentication-Flow.png" width="811" height="352" /></a> Two Factor SSH Authentication Flow[/caption]

It occurs to me that the best way to achieve this is to use the /etc/passwd file to direct accounts to the correct intermediate shell, /bin/scponly if it is a file upload / download account, and /bin/yubishell if it is an interactive account.

To support my authentication flow we use a slightly modified jailed shell for interactive users.
<pre class="lang:default decode:true">#!/bin/bash

# name: /bin/yubishell
#
# desc: verify users OTP with YubiCloud before spawning shell.
TRUSTED_KEYS_FILE=/etc/yubikeyid
YUBICO_API_ID=0000

STD="\\033[0;39m"
OK="\\033[1;32m[i]$STD"
ERR="\\033[1;31m[e]$STD"

##################################################
## Disconnect clients trying to exit the script ##
##################################################
trap disconnect INT

disconnect() {
  sleep 1
  kill -9 $PPID
  exit 1
}

if test -z "$USER"
then
  disconnect
fi

####################################
## Get user-trusted yubikeys list ##
####################################
if [ ! -f $TRUSTED_KEYS_FILE ]
then
  disconnect
fi

TRUSTED_KEYS=`grep "${USER}:" $TRUSTED_KEYS_FILE | sed -e "s/${USER}://" | sed -e 's/:/\n/g'`

#######################################
## Get the actual OTP                ##
#######################################
echo -ne "\033[47;42mYubikey for \`$USER\`:\033[00m "
read -s  OTP
echo
KEY_ID=${OTP:0:12}

#######################################
## Iterate through trusted keys list ##
#######################################
for trusted in ${TRUSTED_KEYS[@]}
do
  if test "$KEY_ID" = "$trusted"
  then
    if wget "https://api.yubico.com/wsapi/verify?id=$YUBICO_API_ID&amp;otp=$OTP" -O - 2&gt; /dev/null | grep "status=OK" &gt; /dev/null
    then
      exec "/bin/bash"
      disconnect
    else
      disconnect
    fi
  fi
done
disconnect</pre>
With the /bin/yubishell in place all that remains is to assign our YubiKey users by modifying their default shell.
<pre>aijayadams:x:1000:1000:Aijay Adams,,,:/home/aijayadams:/bin/yubishell
aijayadams_scp:x:1001:1000:Aijay Adams SCP,,,:/home/aijayadams_scp:/bin/scponly</pre>
And that's it folks! It's a simple way to introduce YubiKey Two Factor Authentication, using the YubiCloud Web Service for OTP verification on your Linux server without giving up Private Key based authentication!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>189</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-01-18 03:32:32</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>ssh-authentication-private-key-yubikey</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	<item>
				<title>Hurricane Electric IPv6 Certification</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2013/01/hurricane-electric-ipv6-certification/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 28 Jan 2013 22:04:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://aijay.id.au/blog/?p=215</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Yesterday was the Australia Day public holiday, and in an attempt to avoid doing any real work I ran through the <a href="http://ipv6.he.net/certification/cert-main.php">HE IPv6 Certification</a> program. It's a fun set of tasks which serve as a nice refresher on basic UNIX (or Windows if you are that way inclined) service configuration.

The program takes you from basic IPv6 connectivity, to having a number of services capable of serving the needs of IPv6 only hosts. Did I mention it's completely free?

Highly recommend as a rainy day activity.

<a href="http://ipv6.he.net/certification/scoresheet.php?pass_name=aijayadams" target="_blank"><img style="border: 0; width: 229px; height: 137px;" alt="IPv6 Certification Badge for aijayadams" src="https://ipv6.he.net/certification/create_badge.php?pass_name=aijayadams&amp;badge=3" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_date>2013-01-29 08:04:21</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-01-28 22:04:21</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>hurricane-electric-ipv6-certification</wp:post_name>

	<item>
				<title>OS X Folder Actions for Media Conversion (mkv to mp4)</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2013/02/os-x-folder-actions-for-media-conversion-mkv-to-mp4/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 Feb 2013 09:50:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://aijay.id.au/blog/?p=220</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[My dear boyfriend, lover of the GUI recently issued a request. Even though ffmpeg provides a super quick, super easy way to repackage mkv files to mp4 without re-encoding any of the media contained within he wanted a GUI to do the job.

After about a minute of trying to make handbrake passthrough video I gave up and used OS X’s Folder Actions feature to bind a folder to a job. That way, all he needs to do is place the .mkv files into a special folder and wait. In a few minutes, BAM!, shiny new .mp4 container without any re-encoding.
<!--more-->
My technique uses ffmpeg to do all the actual work, so you will need to install it first. Fortunately, MacPorts and Google make this pretty easy. If you don't have ffmpeg installed <a href="http://www.google.com/search?q=installing%20ffmpeg%20with%20macports">go here</a> for instructions.

First step is to put a simple wrapper around ffmpeg which passes the correct parametres. I put this script into my path at /usr/local/bin, so that I could use it by hand if the need ever arose.

<address style="padding-left: 30px;">Don't forget to run 'chmod o+x /usr/local/bin/mkv_2_mp4' (or whatever your script is called) to make it executable!</address><address><code> #!/bin/bash
OLDFILE=$1
BASE=${OLDFILE%\.*}.mkv
if [ "${BASE}" == "${OLDFILE}" ]; then
NEWFILE=${OLDFILE%\.*}.mp4
if [ ! -f "$NEWFILE" ] ; then
/opt/local/bin/ffmpeg -i "${OLDFILE}" -acodec copy -vcodec copy "${NEWFILE}"
rm -rf "${OLDFILE}"
fi
fi
</code></address>Next you will need to write an Apple Script which can be attached as the Folder Action.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-221" alt="Folder Action Script" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Screen-Shot-2013-02-05-at-8.32.16-PM.png" width="716" height="495" />

Once you are happy with your script it will need to be copied to "/Library/Scripts/Folder Action Scripts". With the script in place you can select the folder to bind the action.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-222" alt="Folder Action" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Screen-Shot-2013-02-05-at-8.34.10-PM.png" width="319" height="491" />

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-223" alt="Select Folder Action" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Screen-Shot-2013-02-05-at-8.37.23-PM.png" width="542" height="467" />

And that's it, with the Apple Script attached to the folder you should be done! Try dragging an mkv file in and having it repackaged as an mp4. Simple.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>220</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-02-05 19:50:30</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-02-05 09:50:30</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>os-x-folder-actions-for-media-conversion-mkv-to-mp4</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="apple-script"><![CDATA[apple script]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="bash"><![CDATA[bash]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="ffmpeg"><![CDATA[ffmpeg]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="just-nerdy"><![CDATA[Just Nerdy]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="mac"><![CDATA[mac]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="media"><![CDATA[Media]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="media"><![CDATA[Media]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="mkv"><![CDATA[mkv]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="mp4"><![CDATA[mp4]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="os-x"><![CDATA[os x]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="tech-stuff"><![CDATA[Tech Stuff]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wpas_done_all</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>dsq_thread_id</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1869536907]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>cwan3 BGP Diverse Management </title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2013/10/cwan3-bgp-diverse-management/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 Oct 2013 08:54:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://aijay.id.au/blog/?p=228</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[cwan3 is built with Ubiquity wireless equipment and MikroTik routers, there are a number of provisioning and assurance applications running inside the network. These applications and services are available locally and often with redundant access for network mangers within the cwan3 environment, outside of cwan these applications have been accessible via a single path. 
<!--more-->
The problem, unsurprisingly, was that when a problem arose anywhere in the path used to provide external access alarms and management access were unavailable. To combat this issue we now use redundant Internet connections with diverse cwan3 network paths to tunnel to remote management sites. Below is the (very simple) configuration from the cwan3 Mikrotiks and the remote management Junos router.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_230" align="aligncenter" width="528"]<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/cwan_routing.png"><img class="size-full wp-image-230" alt="cwan3 Management Connectivity" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/cwan_routing.png" width="528" height="496" /></a> cwan3 Management Connectivity[/caption]

<strong>Juniper SRX</strong> Remote Management
[enlighter]
aijayadams@gw> show configuration protocols bgp group un-bgp    
type external;
multihop;
export export-local;
peer-as 65400;
local-as 65005;
neighbor 10.4.0.10 {
    local-preference 150;
    local-address 10.4.0.9;
}
neighbor 10.4.0.14 {
    local-preference 200;
    local-address 10.4.0.13;
}
[/enlighter]

<strong>Mikrotik</strong> cwan3 Router
[enlighter]
[admin@nickgw01] /routing bgp> export
# oct/20/2013 09:44:33 by RouterOS 6.4
# software id = JF7C-ISQ4
#
/routing bgp instance
set default as=65400 out-filter=bgp-out redistribute-connected=yes redistribute-ospf=yes
/routing bgp peer
add multihop=yes name=deux.aijay.id.au remote-address=10.4.0.9 remote-as=65005 ttl=default
[/enlighter]

<strong>Mikrotik</strong> cwan3 Router
[enlighter]
[admin@ig01.england.id.au] /routing bgp> export
# oct/20/2013 09:55:39 by RouterOS 6.4
# software id = AJR2-MYB6
#
/routing bgp instance
set default as=65400 out-filter=bgp-out redistribute-connected=yes redistribute-ospf=yes
add as=65200 name=vps out-filter=vps-bgp-out redistribute-connected=yes redistribute-ospf=yes router-id=10.10.10.6
/routing bgp peer
add multihop=yes name=aijay remote-address=10.4.0.13 remote-as=65005 ttl=default
[/enlighter]]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
