	<item>
				<title>pygame 1.9.1 OS X 10.9 Mavericks</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2014/01/pygame-1-9-1-os-x-10-9-mavericks/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 12 Jan 2014 05:11:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://aijay.id.au/blog/?p=259</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I've been playing with the Bitcraze CrazyFlie lately and it's loads of fun. The have great resources which explain how to build the software on most operating systems, however I had a little trouble with the Mac instructions (whether that's because of 10.9 or oddities of my setup is unknown).

Anyway, summary statement is I got the client working by following the instructions at <a href="http://wiki.bitcraze.se/projects:crazyflie:pc_utils:install">http://wiki.bitcraze.se/projects:crazyflie:pc_utils:install</a>, and then building pygame 1.9.1 from source. When you do this there are a couple of things to keep in mind.

For some reason it looks in the wrong place for SDL, you can correct this in the Setup file.
<pre>SDL = -I/usr/local/include/SDL/ -L/usr/local/lib -lSDL</pre>
Secondly there are some assembly instructions which don't seem to work. To fix this we replace the two occurrences of movsxl in the file src/scale_mmx64.c with movslq.
<pre>src/scale_mmx64.c:499:27: error: invalid instruction mnemonic 'movsxl'</pre>
Once you've made these updates go ahead and install pygame with the 'python setup.py install' command.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>SRX 110 IPv6 on Internode</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2014/02/srx-110-ipv6-on-internode/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 Feb 2014 08:50:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://aijay.id.au/blog/?p=285</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I'm sure you all know the last couple of releases of Junos for SRX branch series have been working super hard to get DHCPv6 PD working properly. As a newcomer to the world of ISPs offering native IPv6 I was quite excited to get connected, and immediately disappointed that all my googling on the topic of "SRX Internode IPv6" and similar terms only turned up posts from years ago lamenting Junipers failing to include the features in their then (and now) much touted SRX platform.

So after a little bit of playing around I give you a mostly OK Internode IPv6 PD Client configuration for the SRX110 running 12.1X46-D10.2.
<pre class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="java">aijayadams@gw&gt; show dhcpv6 client binding detail 

Client Interface: pp0.0
     Hardware Address:             b0:a8:6e:68:e1:20
     State:                        BOUND(DHCPV6_CLIENT_STATE_BOUND)
     ClientType:                   STATEFULL
     Lease Expires:                2014-02-19 23:28:30 UTC
     Lease Expires in:             5897 seconds
     Lease Start:                  2014-02-19 21:28:29 UTC
     Bind Type:                    IA_PD
     Client DUID:                  LL0x29-b0:a8:6e:68:e1:20
     Rapid Commit:                 Off
     Server Ip Address:            fe80::224:14ff:fe9a:b910
     Client IP Prefix:             2001:44b8:3132:d600::/56

DHCP options:
    Name: server-identifier, Value: LL0x1-00:24:14:9a:b9:10
    Name: sip-server-domain, Value: .sipinternodeon.net
    Name: dns-recursive-server, Value: 2001:44b8:1::1,2001:44b8:2::2
    Name: domain-serch-list
    Name: sntp, Value: 2001:44b8:1::1</pre>
As you can see there it essentially works, the lease comes in from Internode and the first /64 is used by the RA configured on vlan.100 to address the LAN.

<!--more-->

There is still something not quite right about the setup (or the implementation), you can see errors in the DHCPv6 counters and I've had the SRX meltdown to the point of pulling the power twice already.
<pre class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="java">aijayadams@gw&gt; show dhcpv6 client statistics        

=======================================================
Dhcpv6 Packets dropped:
    Total               14
    Bad Send            14

Messages received:
    DHCPV6_ADVERTISE           4 
    DHCPV6_REPLY               17 
    DHCPV6_RECONFIGURE         0 

Messages sent:
    DHCPV6_DECLINE             0 
    DHCPV6_SOLICIT             18 
    DHCPV6_INFORMATION_REQUEST 0 
    DHCPV6_RELEASE             3 
    DHCPV6_REQUEST             4 
    DHCPV6_CONFIRM             0 
    DHCPV6_RENEW               13 
    DHCPV6_REBIND              0</pre>
So without anything more, here is my config...
<pre class="EnlighterJSRAW" data-enlighter-language="java">## Last commit: 2014-02-19 07:33:26 UTC by aijayadams
version 12.1X46-D10.2;
system {
    host-name gw;
    domain-name in.aijay.id.au;
    root-authentication {
        encrypted-password "&lt;PW&gt;"; ## SECRET-DATA
    }
    name-server {
        8.8.8.8;
    }
    login {
        user aijayadams {
            full-name "Aijay Adams";
            uid 2002;
            class super-user;
            authentication {
                encrypted-password "&lt;PW&gt;"; ## SECRET-DATA
            }
        }
    }
    services {
        ssh {
            root-login deny;
        }
        dhcp-local-server {
            group in_aijay_id_au_DHCP {
                interface vlan.100;
            }
        }
    }
}
interfaces {
    interface-range in_aijay_id_au {
        member-range fe-0/0/0 to fe-0/0/7;
        unit 0 {
            family ethernet-switching {
                vlan {
                    members in_aijay_id_au_VLAN;
                }
            }
        }
    }
    at-1/0/0 {
        mtu 1540;
        encapsulation ethernet-over-atm;
        atm-options {
            vpi 8;
        }
        dsl-options {
            operating-mode auto;
        }
        unit 0 {
            encapsulation ppp-over-ether-over-atm-llc;
            vci 8.35;
        }
    }
    pp0 {                               
        unit 0 {
            ppp-options {
                pap {
                    default-password "&lt;PW&gt;"; ## SECRET-DATA
                    local-name "&lt;username&gt;@internode.on.net";
                    passive;
                }
            }
            pppoe-options {
                underlying-interface at-1/0/0.0;
                idle-timeout 0;
                auto-reconnect 2;
                client;
            }
            family inet {
                mtu 1460;
                negotiate-address;
            }
            family inet6 {
                dhcpv6-client {
                    client-type statefull;
                    client-ia-type ia-pd;
                    update-router-advertisement {
                        interface vlan.100;
                    }
                    client-identifier duid-type duid-ll;
                }
            }
        }
    }
    vlan {
        unit 100 {
            family inet {
                address 10.58.68.254/24;
            }
            family inet6;
        }
    }
}
routing-options {
    rib inet6.0 {
        static {
            route ::/0 {
                qualified-next-hop pp0.0;
            }
        }
    }
    static {
        route 0.0.0.0/0 {               
            qualified-next-hop pp0.0;
        }
    }
}

security {
    forwarding-options {
        family {
            inet6 {
                mode flow-based;
            }
        }
    }
    nat {
        source {
            rule-set src-nat-internet-bound {
                from zone in_aijay_id_au;
                to zone internet;
                rule internet-bound {
                    match {
                        source-address 10.58.68.0/24;
                    }
                    then {
                        source-nat {
                            interface;
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
        }

    }
    policies {
        from-zone in_aijay_id_au to-zone internet {
            policy in_aijay_id_au-to-internet {
                match {
                    source-address any;
                    destination-address any;
                    application any;
                }
                then {
                    permit;
                }
            }
        }
    }
    zones {
        security-zone in_aijay_id_au {
            interfaces {
                vlan.100 {
                    host-inbound-traffic {
                        system-services {
                            ping;
                            ssh;
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        security-zone internet {
            interfaces {
                pp0.0 {
                    host-inbound-traffic {
                        system-services {
                            dhcpv6;
                            ping;
                        }
                    }                   
                }
            }
        }
    }
}
access {
    address-assignment {
        pool in_aijay_id_au_POOL {
            family inet {
                network 10.58.68.0/24;
                range dyn_addresses {
                    low 10.58.68.120;
                    high 10.58.68.200;
                }
                dhcp-attributes {
                    domain-name in.aijay.id.au;
                    name-server {
                        192.231.203.132;
                        192.231.203.3;
                    }
                    router {
                        10.58.68.254;
                    }                   
                }
            }
        }
    }
}
applications {
    application openvpn {
        protocol udp;
        destination-port 1194;
    }
}
vlans {
    in_aijay_id_au_VLAN {
        vlan-id 100;
        l3-interface vlan.100;
    }
}</pre>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>285</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-02-19 18:50:04</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-02-19 08:50:04</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>srx-110-ipv6-on-internode</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="just-nerdy"><![CDATA[Just Nerdy]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="networking"><![CDATA[Networking]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wpas_done_all</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Junos OS PyEZ - Taking the first step</title>
		<link>https://aijay.id.au/blog/2014/04/junos-os-pyez-taking-the-first-step/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 18 Apr 2014 04:55:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Aijay Adams]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://aijay.id.au/blog/?p=292</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It's been a long time coming, but this morning I finally found the time to take the first steps in exploring Junos OS PyEZ.
<blockquote><em>Junos OS PyEZ</em> is a Python "micro-framework" to remotely manage or automate Junos OS devices. The user is <strong><em>NOT</em></strong> required to be a software programmer, have sophisticated knowledge of Junos OS, or have a complex understanding of the Junos OS XML API.</blockquote>
Installing the python library is superbly simple with pip.
<pre>pip install junos-eznc</pre>
Given this was a first set I haven't done anything too complex, this script finds the active route to cwan management from my SRX, with no unstructured access to the Junos router.
<pre>#!/usr/local/bin/python2.7
from pprint import pprint as pp
from jnpr.junos import Device
import dns.resolver

# cwan3 mgmt route
cwan_rt = "10.3.23.0/25"
# cwan3 name server
cwan_ns = ["10.58.68.5"]


def cwan_revdns(ip):
    on_cwan_dns = dns.resolver.Resolver()
    on_cwan_dns.nameservers = cwan_ns
    addr = dns.reversename.from_address(ip)
    return str(on_cwan_dns.query(addr,"PTR")[0])



dev = Device(host='10.58.68.254', user='aijayadams' )
dev.open()


from jnpr.junos.factory import loadyaml
globals().update( loadyaml('junos_table_definitions.yml') )

rt_table = RouteTable(dev)
rt_table.get()

interface_table = InterfaceTable(dev)
interface_table.get()

print "cwan3 to %s via %s" % (cwan_revdns(rt_table[cwan_rt].to), rt_table[cwan_rt].via)

dev.close()</pre>
And the YAML (junos_table_definitions.yml)
<pre>---
RouteTable:
  rpc: get-route-information
  args_key: destination
  item: route-table/rt
  key: rt-destination
  view: ActiveRouteView
 
ActiveRouteView:
  groups:
    nh: 'rt-entry[current-active]/nh[selected-next-hop]'
  fields_nh:
    to: to
    via: via
 
InterfaceTable:
  rpc: get-interface-information
  args_key: interface-name
  item: physical-interface/logical-interface
  key: name
  view: InterfaceView
 
InterfaceView:
  fields:
    description: description
</pre>
[caption id="attachment_296" align="aligncenter" width="625"]<a href="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Screenshot-2014-04-18-14.25.25.png"><img class="wp-image-296 size-large" src="https://aijay.id.au/blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Screenshot-2014-04-18-14.25.25-1024x574.png" alt="PyEZ Hello World" width="625" height="350" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>292</wp:post_id>
